Graphical abstract The surface coating layer Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 helps stabilize the surface oxygen and lattice oxygen simultaneously of the Ni-rich material during cycling, realizing 91% capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 0.3 C in ASSLB. To satisfy the demands of modern society for high-energy–density sulfide-based all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs), Ni-rich cathode materials have gained much attention for their high capacity and energy density. However, their practical deployment is hindered by accelerated interface degradation and capacity decay originating from surface oxygen release and lattice oxygen activation during prolonged cycling. In this study, Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 was successfully coated on the surface of LiNi0.94Co0.05Mn0.01O2. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations first elucidate a “point-to-point” anchoring mechanism where each surface oxygen atom coordinates with single species (Ti/Nb/B) offered by Ti x NbB(1− x )C2, which forms robust O–M bonds and sustain a stable interface structure. The electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) reveals the segregation of Ti/Nb toward subsurface layers during cycling, creating an optimized lattice oxygen coordination environment and suppressing oxygen activation. The dual oxygen stabilization mechanism dramatically improves the reversibility of phase transition and the structural stability of the Ni-rich cathode materials. Moreover, Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 as the protective layer decreases mechanical strain and suppresses the parasitic reactions. Consequently, the engineered cathode delivers 91% capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 0.3 C, suggesting excellent cycling stability. The research delivers a new design philosophy for the coating layer that can stabilize surface oxygen. Furthermore, the atomistic understanding of the structure–property relationship of the Ni-rich cathode materials provides valuable guidance for the future design of new cathode materials with superior structural stability in ASSLBs. Keywords Ni-rich cathode Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 coating “Point-to-point” anchoring Element segregation All-solid-state lithium batteries Long cycle stability 1 Introduction The exponential growth of electric vehicles and portable electronics has precipitated an unprecedented demand for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with exceptional energy density (>400 Wh kg−1) and intrinsic safety characteristics. While conventional liquid-electrolyte LIBs dominate current markets, theoretical maximum energy density and flammability risk still impede their long-term development [1,2]. These critical challenges have driven researchers to focus on all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs). Using solid-state electrolytes can improve the energy density, security, and stability of lithium-ion batteries, further promoting the development of power batteries[3,4]. In recent years, Ni-rich cathode materials (LiNi x Co y Mn1− x − y O2) have emerged as preeminent cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries due to their high theoretical capacity and elevated plateau voltage [5,6]. Particularly, single-crystal Ni-rich cathode materials have garnered significant attention owing to their higher structural integrity and reduced intergranular interfaces[7]. While the high-valence nickel species facilitate the attainment of a higher theoretical capacity (approximately 274 mA h g−1), they can also impair the long-term structural stability. As the degree of delithiation deepens, highly oxidized transition metal (TM) ions attract electrons from the TM–O bond. At the same time, the electrostatic repulsion between TMO6 slabs decreases, weakening the intensity of TM–O and O–TM–O bonds. Under the additional thermodynamic-driven effect, new O–O chemical bonds easily form, resulting in oxygen vacancies appearing [8,9]. The presence of surface oxygen vacancies induces the unstable Oα− (α < 2) in the bulk to migrate towards the outermost layer, bringing about the lattice oxygen loss during long-term charge and discharge processes (Fig. 1 a). Furthermore, the oxygen vacancies accumulation significantly lowers the energy barrier for nickel cation migration, thus accelerating the transition from layered to spinal and rock-salt phases. Ultimately, the oxygen evolution culminates in structural degradation and particle fracture, which causes the electrochemical properties of the material to decline [10,11]. Surface coating is a prevalent modification strategy employed to enhance the performance of Ni-rich cathode materials. The functions of coatings are manifold: 1) Acting as a physical barrier to suppress side reactions between the cathode materials and electrolytes; 2) Serving as a conductive layer, enhancing the interfacial charge transfer; 3) Providing structural stability and reducing stress on materials during cycling [12,13]. Constructing an optimal coating layer, in conjunction with introducing elements capable of stabilizing oxygen within it, can be a pivotal strategy to address the critical challenge of enhancing surface oxygen stability while achieving the aforementioned functions. Metal oxides have garnered significant attention and utilization in liquid lithium-ion batteries for their exceptional stability and capacity to react with HF, reducing electrolyte acidity [14–16]. However, their inferior electron transport properties may hinder rapid electron migration inside composite cathodes in ASSLBs [17,18]. In recent years, transition metal carbides (TMCs) have attracted extensive attention in energy storage. Their high conductivity and chemical stability render them promising for utilization in the field of lithium-ion batteries [19–21]. While some studies suggest that carbon-based conductive agents may induce side reactions with sulfide solid electrolytes, the potential mechanism lies in the oxygen-containing functional groups on the carbon surface, which may trigger the redox reactions of the sulfide solid electrolytes [22,23]. It is noteworthy that conventional TMCs do not possess intrinsic oxygen-containing functional groups. Besides, their distinctive structural features offer enhanced active sites, expanding their application as catalysts [24,25]. The feature has prompted further investigation into the potential benefits of enhancing surface oxygen anchoring through increased transition metal ions at active sites. In transition metal elements, Nb has been extensively utilized in modified Ni-rich cathode materials for its strong binding energy with O (Nb–O: 726 kJ mol−1, Ni–O: 382 kJ mol−1) [26,27]. Meanwhile, as a high valence element, Nb can change the microstructure of cathode materials to resist crack formation and improve cycle stability. However, the presence of Nb5+ is likely to induce the reduction of Ni3+ and increase the risk of the Li+/Ni2+ disorder [28]. Additionally, Ti can also contribute to strengthening the chemical bond between metal and oxygen. Though the binding energy of the Ti–O bond is lower than that of the Nb–O bond (Ti–O: 662 kJ mol−1), the incorporation of Ti can inhibit the cation mixing of Li+ and Ni2+ ions [29,30]. Furthermore, it can improve the intrinsic conductivity of the material and help increase capacity [31]. Therefore, we choose to introduce both Ti and Nb into the carbide coating to achieve the high-capacity and long-cycle stability of Ni-rich cathode materials in ASSLBs through their synergistic effect. In addition, a small amount of B was introduced to enhance the covalent interaction in the carbide. The coating with covalent bonds, ionic bonds, and metal bonds has better resistance to stress changes caused by volume expansion, which may contribute to the stability of Ni-rich cathode materials during lithium-ion (de)intercalation [32]. Ultimately, we coated Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 on the surface of LiNi0.94Co0.05Mn0.01O2 (NCM) for the first time (designed as NCM@TNB) and successfully achieved a dual stabilization effect on the surface and lattice oxygen:1) “Point-to-point” anchoring of oxygen atoms on the surface. Compared with conventional oxide coating, the independent binding of Ti, Nb, and B atoms with oxygen atoms significantly enhances the bonding strength with surface oxygen and suppresses the generation of oxygen vacancies in long cycles (Fig. 1b and c) [33]. 2) Inhibit the outward migration of Oα−(α ＜ 2). During the cycling process, Ti and Nb will segregate towards near bulk, which can replace the TM sites in NCM and stabilize the lattice oxygen. The synergistic stabilization strategy endows NCM@TNB with exceptional cycling durability, keeping a 91% capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 0.3 C (2.7–4.3 V vs. Li+/Li). In conclusion, our work provides more ideas for expanding the coating phase of Ni-rich cathode materials and stabilizing the structure of cathode materials, offering a solution for designing high-energy–density all-solid-state lithium batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis The Argyrodite Li5.5PS4.5Cl1.5 SSE was synthesized by the solid-state ball-milling method. Firstly, according to the stoichiometric ratio, weighed Li2S (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%), P2S5 (Aladdin, 99.9%), and LiCl (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%). Put them into a zirconia jar and seal them. The precursor was obtained by ball milling at a speed of 600 r min−1 for 16 h. Then, it was transferred into a quartz tube, sealed, and calcined at 500 ℃ for 6 h to obtain the Li5.5PS4.5Cl1.5 SSE. All steps were completed under the protection of argon. The surface-modified NCM@TNB material was synthesized using the sol–gel method. The synthesis path of the material is as follows: dissolved the stoichiometric isopropyl titanate (Aladdin, 97%), niobium pentaethoxide (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%) and vacuum dried H3BO3 (Ti:Nb:B molar ratio = 1:1:1) into 5 mL absolute ethanol and stirred thoroughly. After complete mixing, commercial NCM powders were added to the sol system and stirred for 5 h. The above process was carried out in a glovebox filled with argon gas (O2 and H2O below 0.1 ppm). Then, the solvent was evaporated using ultrasound at 80 ℃ to obtain the precursor. Transferred the precursor powders into a ceramic boat and annealed under 650 ℃ for 5 h with O2/Ar mixed gas to obtain the final product. The uncoated cathode powders are used as a comparison sample. 2.2 Batteries fabrication and electrochemical tests Preparation of the cathode for all-solid-state batteries: added the cathode active materials, LPSCl SSEs and VGCF into an agate mortar and ground thoroughly with a ratio of 6:3.7:0.3. Assembly of all-solid-state batteries: cold pressing around 10 mg cathode and 100 mg LPSCl electrolyte at 140 MPa for 2 min, finally added Li-In alloy (Li:In = 1:6 M ratio) on the other side and pressed with the same pressure. All processes were finished in an argon-filled glovebox (O2 and H2O below 0.01 ppm). The rate performance of ASSLBs was tested at different rates (0.1–2 C) between 2.1–3.7 V (vs. Li+/Li-In, corresponding to 2.7–4.3 V vs. Li+/Li ). Moreover, cycle performance was tested at 0.3 C (1 C corresponds to 200 mA h g−1). All the tests were using the Land CT2001A battery test system. The ex-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were conducted using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660E), with the amplitude voltage between 0.1 Hz and 1 MHz at 10 mV. Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) measurements were charging/discharging the batteries at 0.1 C for 45 min and rest for 2 h between 2.1–3.7 V (vs. Li+/Li-In). For the cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements, the cycles were recorded at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. 2.3 Materials characterization Using X-ray Diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å) in a 2θ range from 10° to 90° to research the crystal structure of NCM and NCM@TNB. Rietveld refinements have been done with the GSAS Ⅱ software. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with etching was finished by PHI VersaProbe Ⅲ XPS with an Al-K α (1486.6 eV). Thermo IRIS performed the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) tests. The morphology and microstructure of the cathodes were studied by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi, S-4800) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Themis Z). After focused ion beam (FIB, Helios Nano Lab), high-angle angular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM, FEI Themis Z) was used to further obtain more messages about the cathodes. The steps are as follows: dissolve the cycled sample in anhydrous ethanol, sonicate, filter, and dry to obtain the cathode material sample. Dilute it and transfer the supernatant to a copper mesh, then observe and study it under a transmission electron microscope. Local structures of Ni, Co, and Mn atoms were explored by X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS). Ni, Co, and Mn L-edge XAFS spectra were acquired at the 1W1B beamline in the BSRF. The X-ray beam was monochromatized with a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator. A detuning of about 10% was performed to suppress the high harmonic content. The Athena module was used to process the data. The instrument EMXplus finished the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements. The battery testing system and the mass spectrometry system were combined to perform the in-situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) experiments. 2.4 Modeling and calculation methods All the calculations are performed in the framework of the density functional theory with the projector-augmented plane-wave method, as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package [34]. The generalized gradient approximation proposed by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh of (PBE) is selected for the exchange–correlation potential [35]. The cut-off energy for the plane wave was set to 480 eV. The energy criterion was set to 10−4 eV in the iterative solution of the Kohn-Sham equation. The PAW potentials employed in this study are as follows: for Li, the valence electron configuration is 2 s 1; for Ti, the valence electrons are 3d 2 4s 2; for Nb, the valence electrons are 4d 4 5s 1; for Ni, the valence electrons are 3d 8 4s 2; for O, the valence electrons are 2s 2 2p 4; for C, the valence electrons are 2s 2 2p 2; and for B, the valence electrons are 2s 2 2p 1. All the structures are relaxed until the residual forces on the atoms have declined to less than 0.02 eV Å−1. To avoid interlaminar interactions, a vacuum spacing of 20 Å is applied perpendicular to the slab. For the Brillouin zone sampling, a 6 × 6 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh is used to ensure accurate integration of the electronic states in the reciprocal space. 3 Results and discussion In this investigation, we first synthesized boron-doped titanium carbide and niobium carbide-coated cathode materials (denoted as NCM@TB and NCM@NB, respectively) through a sol–gel method followed by controlled high-temperature annealing. Structural characterization by XRD analysis revealed a remarkable enhancement in the (003)/(104) peak intensity ratio from 0.97 for pristine NCM to 2.02 for NCM@TB (Fig. S1), suggesting effective suppression of Li/Ni cation mixing. Subsequent Rietveld refinement analysis further confirmed expanded lattice parameters in NCM@NB (Fig. S2 and Table S1), implying distinct structural modifications induced by different elements. Electrical conductivity measurements (Fig. S3) demonstrated that titanium incorporation significantly improved the electronic transport properties, elevating conductivity from 5.485 × 10−2 (NCM) to 6.542 × 10−2 S cm−1. In contrast, the introduction of Nb exhibited negligible change (5.402 × 10−2 S cm−1). The electrochemical measurements show that NCM@TB displayed superior Coulombic efficiency (CE) and discharge capacity, whereas NCM@NB exhibited enhanced cycling stability despite lower CE (Fig. S4 and Table S2). These complementary behaviors suggest that the synergistic integration of Ti and Nb in the carbide coating layer is essential for achieving superior electrochemical performance, where Ti optimizes charge transfer kinetics, and Nb stabilizes structural integrity during prolonged cycling. The NCM@TNB was synthesized following an identical preparation process to ensure comparability. In the SEM images (Fig. S5), NCM and NCM@TNB particles exhibit single-crystalline morphology with a uniform dimension of approximately 1 μm. The rough surface of NCM@TNB indicates the existence of a coating layer. Quantitative elemental analysis through ICP-OES (Table S3) confirms the successful incorporation of Ti, Nb, and B. As shown in Fig. S1, XRD patterns demonstrated that the NCM@TNB maintains phase purity with characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to the R-3 m space group of the layered α-NaFeO2 phase, consistent with previous reports. The distinct splitting of adjacent (006)/(102) and (018)/(110) diffraction peaks further verified the well-ordered layered structure[36,37]. The lattice parameter comparative analysis (Table S1) reveals an expanded c-axis dimension in NCM@TNB, attributable to the ionic radius disparity between Ti3+(0.67 Å) and Nb5+(0.64 Å) and original transition metal ions (Ni3+: 0.56 Å; Co3+: 0.545 Å; Mn4+: 0.53 Å) [38–40]. This lattice expansion along the c-axis effectively facilitates Li+ (de)intercalation kinetics. The thickness and compositional characteristics of the coating layer were systematically investigated through TEM coupled with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping. As evidenced in Fig. 2 (a), a uniform surface coating with an average thickness of 10 nm was resolved on the NCM substrate. High-resolution EDS mapping (Fig. 2b–e and Fig. S6) revealed homogeneous spatial distributions of Ti, Nb, and B elements across the NCM@TNB surface. Double aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (Cs-STEM) was employed to gain deeper insights into the atomic-scale microstructure. Crystallographic analysis conducted along different zone axes yielded critical structural information. The atomic-resolution image in Fig. 2(f) displays lattice fringes with a measured interplanar spacing of 0.456 1/Å, in excellent agreement with the (002) plane of TiNbC2 (theoretical d-spacing: 0.456 1/Å, Fig. 2g). Further characterization along another zone axis (Fig. 2j) revealed two spacings of 0.438 and 0.398 1/Å, corresponding respectively to the (200) and (111) planes of TiNbC2 (reference spacings: 0.456 and 0.395 1/Å, Fig. 2k). Remarkably, the atomic phase overlap analysis (Fig. 2h and l) demonstrated congruous crystallographic alignment between the coating layer and TiNbC2. These comprehensive depictions confirm the successful construction of Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 on the surface of NCM. Thus, we simulated the images of the coating layer using abTEM (Fig. 2i and m). XPS was employed to elucidate the surface chemical state of NCM and NCM@TNB as an adjunct. As shown in Fig. S7, the Ni 2p 3/2 spectra of NCM and NCM@TNB exhibited characteristic peaks at 855.6 and 855.3 eV, predominantly corresponding to Ni3+. The peak in the Ni 2p 3/2 spectra of NCM@TNB showed a slight shift toward low binding energy compared with NCM, which indicated the decrease of the element valence state. The discrepancy could be attributed to a charge compensation induced by the partial substitution of Ni3+ sites with Nb5+, accompanied by the reduction of some Ni3+ to Ni2+. The Co 2p and Mn 2p spectra contain peaks consistent with the ideal valent of Co3+ (780 eV) and Mn4+ (642 eV) [41,42]. The Ti 2p spectrum presents two distinct binding energy peaks at 457.77 and 463.77 eV, a feature of Ti3+ species. Concurrently, the Nb 3d spectrum displays signature peaks at 206.33 and 209.09 eV, confirming the presence of Nb5+. The signal in the B 1 s spectrum around 191.21 eV is consistent with B3+ [43–45]. The spectral features provide additional evidence for the coverage of the Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 coating layer at the surface of NCM particles (Fig. S8a–c). The longitudinal dispersion situation of different constituents was obtained by XPS etching tests (Fig. S8d–f). The results reveal that the concentrations of Ti3+, Nb5+, and B3+ all undergo progressive attenuation after the etching depth exceeds the thickness of the coating layer. In summary, Ti, Nb, and B mainly exist in the coating layer, which is advantageous for bonding with surface oxygen atoms and enhancing the surface phase stability of the Ni-rich cathode materials. DFT calculations were conducted to verify the stabilization effect of Ti, Nb, and B in the coating layer on the surface oxygen. Atomic-scale simulations probed the pristine LiNiO2 (104) surface and the Ti x NbB(1− x )C2-coated interface. The truncated LiNiO2 (104) surface exhibits two oxygen coordination environments (Fig. S9): (i) surface oxygen atoms coordinated with three Ni and two Li atoms (O1) and (ii) bonded with three Li and two Ni atoms (O2). The calculated average energy of the O 2p states for O1 and O2 were −3.136 and −2.559 eV, respectively. Crucially, the weakened Ni 3d–O 2p hybridization in the surface configurations leads to elevated O 2p states and approaches the Fermi level (E F), promoting surface oxygen instability and making oxygen vacancies easily generated [46]. At the LiNiO2 (104)/Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 (200) heterointerface, each interfacial oxygen atom bonds with the Ti/Nb/B atom (Fig. 3 a), forming a unique “point-to-point” anchoring configuration. The average energy of the O 2p state of three oxygen coordination types was identified through computational analysis: the O coordinated with two Ni, three Li, and one Nb is −3.237 eV (Fig. 3b). When replacing Nb with Ti/B, the energy became −3.935 or −3.191 eV (Fig. 3c and d). The remarkable downward shift of O p-band centers compared to uncoated surface originates from the robust Nb 4d–O 2p and Ti 3d–O 2p hybridization, coupled with a strong covalent B–O bonding. The charge density plot (Fig. 3e and f) further indicates the preferential electron cloud sharing between O and Ti atoms, contrasting with Ni–O interactions. The “point to point” anchoring mechanism constructs a stabilized oxygen coordination environment and suppresses oxygen release. The density of states (DOS) between pristine and coated systems was compared, showing that NCM@TNB has a wider path around the E F than NCM (Fig. 3g and h). The electronic conductivity of NCM@TNB has been determined to be 6.783 × 10−2 S cm−1 (Fig. S3). The result, in conjunction with theoretical calculations, substantiates that the encapsulation of Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 enhances the electronic transport performance of the Ni-rich cathode materials, which is advantageous for enhancing rate performance. To explore the surface electronic structure evolution of Ni, O, Ti, and Nb, a series of EELS measurements were performed on NCM and NCM@TNB after 100 cycles. The cross-sectional HAADF-STEM images of NCM and NCM@TNB were acquired using Cs-STEM. Scanning inward from the surface with a 1 nm interval (λ = 24 nm, pathways were annotated by red arrows, Fig. 4 a and b), then a series of contour plots were obtained after normalizing the scanning results. In the O K-edge spectrum, pre-edge peaks represent the electron transform from the O 1s orbital to the hybrid orbital that the unoccupied O 2p orbital hybridized with the TM-3d orbital [47]. On the surface of bare NCM, the pre-edge peaks of O K-edges display an erratic intensity fluctuation (Fig. 4c), indicating oxygen vacancy accumulation [48]. In contrast, NCM@TNB illustrated uniform O K-edge profiles with broadened peak envelopes in Fig. 4(d), suggesting the stabilized surface oxygen. Similarly, the Ni L-edges of NCM display an anomalous change trend of L3/L2. The higher ratio of Ni L3/L2 corresponds to a more significant Ni reduction, which means hidden trouble for irreversible phase transitions (Fig. 4e) [49]. Although NCM@TNB exhibited attenuated Ni L2 peak intensity from the interior to the surface (Fig. 4f), it originates from the spontaneous charge compensation from Nb5+ [50]. Moreover, the existence of the coating layer inhibits the surface oxygen evolution, so the irreversible phase transition is prevented. Indubitably, the inherent instability of lattice oxygen has been a critical factor that limits the property of Ni-rich layered cathode materials as well [51]. Mechanistic studies reveal that in the crystal structure of Ni-rich cathode material, the eg electron orbital of Ni3+/Ni4+ overlaps with the 2p electron orbital of O2− and generates a σ-type hybrid orbital. Upon charging beyond 4.1 V, holes are generated in the O 2p band and induce oxygen evolution. The escape of lattice oxygen will trigger irreversible phase transitions, particle cracks, and other results that collectively affect the structural integrity and long-cycle stability of the cathode materials [52,53]. The more profound comprehension of the electronic structure in the bulk was investigated by the EELS spectra of NCM and NCM@TNB (scanning starts from a depth of 100 nm, λ = 24 nm; red arrows indicate the pathways, Fig. 4g and h). The confused pre-edge peaks in the O K-edge spectra of NCM indicate that the precipitation of lattice oxygen and local structural disorder is still present in the bulk, as corroborated by the same phenomenon in the Ni K-edge spectra (Fig. 4i and k). In stark contrast, it exhibits well-defined high-intensity pre-edge peaks in the O K-edge spectra of NCM@TNB (Fig. 4j), confirming the effective suppression of oxygen vacancy formation [54]. Furthermore, the maintained intensity ratio of Ni L3/L2 reflects the retention of the layered phase throughout cycling (Fig. 4l) [55]. As shown in Fig. S10a–c, with the scanning depth increases, the intensity of the Ti and Nb M-edges peaks in the EELS spectrum of NCM@TNB rises. Moreover, the Ti M-edge peaks shift to higher energy slightly, which means an increased valence of Ti. The boron detection presented technical challenges due to its low atomic number and the complexity of differentiating it from the carbon signals. XPS depth profiling of NCM@TNB was performed after cycling to overcome the limitation above (Fig. S10d). Compared with the XPS etching spectrum of Ti 2p, Nb 3d, and B 1s before cycling, three elements exhibit a migration behavior toward the bulk. These findings demonstrate that the cations with strong oxygen affinity (Ti3+, Nb5+, and B3+) not only work as surface-stabilizing species but exhibit dynamic segregation toward subsurface regions during cycling and bonding with the lattice oxygen. Under the dual stabilization strategy, the formation and migration of metastable oxygen species (Oα−, α < 2) are effectively suppressed. Eventually, it improves the structural stability of NCM@TNB and is helpful for stable long-term cycling. The changes in oxidation states and local coordination environments for Ni, Co, and Mn in NCM and NCM@TNB were investigated using synchrotron XAFS before and after 50 cycles. As depicted in Fig. 5 (a), the Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectrum of NCM@TNB displays a low-energy shift prior to NCM before cycling, which relates to the unoccupied Ni-4p state through 1s-4p excitation, indicating a decrease of Ni oxidation state (an enlarged image is shown in Fig. S11a) [56]. The observation aligns with the XPS and EELS results. Simultaneously, the Co and Mn K-edges spectra of NCM@TNB also exhibit slight edge shifts (Fig. S11b–e). However, the comparison after cycling demonstrates elevated oxidation states for Co and Mn in NCM@TNB, evidencing an enhanced structural stabilization in the modified cathode. Fig. 5(b) compares the Ni K-edge extended XAFS (EXAFS) of the samples before and after cycling. The NiO6 structures of materials with octahedral symmetry at various stages are displayed. The first peak represents the relationship between Ni and O (Ni–O) in the first coordination shell, while the second peak represents the bond between Ni and other transition metal ions (Ni–M) [57,58]. The results indicate that NCM@TNB exhibits shorter interatomic distances of Ni–O and Ni–M, consistent with the observed Ni K-edge energy shift. Notably, the intensity of Ni–O for NCM@TNB is higher than that for NCM. After cycling, the intensity increases again, confirming the less disordered NiO6 structures in NCM@TNB and the sustained structural stability of NCM@TNB over extended cycles [59]. As shown in Fig. 5(c and d), EPR measurements evaluated the situation for suppressing the oxygen vacancy generation. Both materials exhibited analogous oxygen vacancy concentrations in their pristine states, as evidenced by similar peak intensities and line shapes. Upon charging to 4.3 V, however, NCM displayed a higher peak intensity than NCM@TNB, denoting that more oxygen vacancies were generated in cycling [60]. The phenomenon primarily stems from the structural instability of Ni–O bonds when lithium ions are extensively extracted. In contrast, the oxygen stability of NCM@TNB is effectively improved by the dual stabilization mechanism, and the formation of oxygen vacancy is reduced. In-situ DEMS measurements further quantified the oxygen release situation (Fig. 5e and f). The consequence demonstrated that NCM@TNB has less oxygen release than bare NCM, accompanied by extended charge/discharge time during initial cycling. These observations can be explained by the following: bare NCM has undergone severe phase transitions, hindering the reversible Li+ (de)intercalation and accelerating capacity decay. In comparison, the dual oxygen stabilization in NCM@TNB makes the structure stable. Furthermore, the products of interface side reactions H2S and H2O can be detected (Fig. S12). The lower quantity of H2S and H2O released from a battery with NCM@TNB confirms that the Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 functions as a protective interfacial layer, physically isolating the Ni-rich cathode material from sulfide electrolyte while suppressing parasitic reactions. The inhibition of side reactions and the minimization of structural deterioration provides the potential for the Ni-rich layered oxide cathodes to achieve capacity improvement and stable circulation. To comprehensively assess the effect of surface coating on the microstructure of the Ni-rich cathode materials, NCM and NCM@TNB samples were extracted from batteries after 100 cycles and subjected to high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). As shown in Fig. 6 (a and b), the pristine NCM exhibits severe lattice distortion, manifesting it suffered accumulated lattice stress during cycling [61]. To our delight, NCM@TNB maintains a well-ordered layered structure (Fig. 6i and j). The εxx and εyy strain maps of the NCM and NCM@TNB particles were acquired through the geometric phase analysis (GPA) on TEM images, showing that NCM@TNB has an alleviated strain concentration in any direction (Fig. 6c, d, k, and l). The uneven lithium (de)intercalation causes stress generation, which results in single-crystal particle expansion and contraction. Eventually, they lead to intragranular cracks [62,63]. To further investigate the formation of intragranular cracks, NCM and NCM@TNB particles after cycling were attenuated using a focused ion beam (FIB) technique. The surface morphology and cross-section of the particles were observed (Fig. 6g, h, o, and p). It is evident that numerous cracks are present on the surface of NCM particles. The cross-sectional view also corroborates the existence of cracks extending from the single crystal particle surface to the interior, making the particle prone to fragmentation and impeding the attainment of stable long cycling. In contrast, NCM@TNB particles remain unblemished and intact after cycling. Combining the above results, the element segregation successfully enhances the lattice stability of the Ni-rich cathode material. Furthermore, the coating layer Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 with various bonds assists in enabling the Ni-rich cathode material to adapt to volume expansion, thereby reducing the formation of cracks. Structural degradation is one of the main culprits in Ni-rich cathode materials that leads to capacity decay [61]. HRTEM images confirm the formation of the rock-salt phase by the enlarged lattice pattern of Region I and the corresponding Fast Fourier transform (FFT) image (Fig. 6e, f-1, and f-2). Moreover, severe fissuring exists between the layered phase and the newly formed rock-salt phase (Region II, Fig. 6e, f-3, and f-4). The evidence illustrates that the structure of NCM undergoes severe degradation over cycling. On the contrary, the intact protective layer is still on the surface of NCM@TNB (Region I, Fig. 6m, n-1, and n-2), which assists the core region in keeping a complete layered structure (Region II, Fig. 6m, n-3, and n-4). It indirectly proves that the coating layer achieves an ideal match with NCM, preventing it from detaching during extended cycling. Meanwhile, the surface and lattice oxygen are firmly fixed with Ti, Nb, or B, which stabilize the layered structure. The electrochemical performances were evaluated by constructing ASSLBs using NCM or NCM@TNB as cathode, paired with LPSCl and Li-In anode, operating within 2.7–4.3 V (vs. Li+/Li). As shown in Fig. 7 (a), the rate performance of NCM/LPSCl/Li-In and NCM@TNB/LPSCl/ Li-In were tested, varying from 0.1 to 2 C. NCM@TNB/LPSCl/Li-In exhibits a better initial discharge-specific capacity of 191.4 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and the CE is 75.4%, while the CE of NCM/LPSCl/Li-In only reached 69.8% and the discharge-specific capacity is 175 mA h g−1. As the current increases, NCM@TNB/LPSCl/Li-In shows a weaker capacity decline rate than NCM/LPSCl/Li-In. The phenomenon demonstrates that the favorable electronic conductivity of Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 can facilitate electron transmission in the Ni-rich cathode material, thereby enhancing the rate performance of the Ni-rich cathode material in ASSLBs. Fig. 7(b) shows the cycle stability of NCM/LPSCl/Li-In and NCM@TNB/LPSCl/Li-In at 0.3 C. When the batteries activated at 0.1 C, the CE of NCM only arrived at 70%, whereas that of NCM@TNB can reach 77.09%. It is noteworthy that NCM/LPSCl/Li-In exhibited signs of necrosis after 780 cycles, with the capacity retention decreased to 40%. Surprisingly, NCM@TNB/LPSCl/ Li-In has a capacity retention of 91% after 1000 cycles, which is regarded as an excellent performance compared to the representative counterparts as previously reported (Fig. 7h). During certain periods, the battery capacity declines, primarily attributed to ambient temperature decreases. The results demonstrate that the dual stabilization strategy targeting surface oxygen and lattice oxygen has achieved long-term stable cycling of the Ni-rich cathode material in ASSLBs. A comparison of the charge–discharge curves of NCM/LPSCl/Li-In and NCM@TNB/LPSCl/Li-In (Fig. 7c and d) reveals that the latter exhibits a lower polarization trend and capacity loss during cycling. The comparison suggests that the coating layer offers splendid interface properties and optimized Li+ transfer kinetics. The electrochemical polarization and Li+ diffusivities (DLi+) of the two materials were further evaluated by GITT. Regardless of the charge or discharge state, NCM@TNB exhibits reduced polarizability (Fig. 7f). Fig. 7(g) and Fig. S13 indicate that the DLi+ of NCM and NCM@TNB show a consistent change trend. However, the DLi+ of NCM@TNB is considerably higher than NCM during the discharge process, which suggests its superior kinetics. Differential capacity (dQ/dV) profile curves were also acquired to gain insight into the phase changes and electrochemical polarization (Fig. S14). With cycling, the H2-H3 phase transition peaks of bare NCM display prompt attenuation and even disappear, whereas that of NCM@TNB keeps a relatively stable intensity. As the charging step progresses, the H1→M oxidation peak of NCM exhibits a continuous high-voltage shift compared to NCM@TNB, reflecting the higher electrochemical polarization of NCM [64]. Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) curves show the same change trend of the phase transition peaks (Fig. S15), indicating the improved structural reversibility of NCM@TNB in comparison with NCM [65]. To elucidate the interface dynamics of NCM and NCM@TNB, EIS tests were carried out after 3 and 50 cycles. The fitting results are shown in Fig. S16 and Table S5. At the outset of the cycling, NCM exhibits elevated surface film resistance (R sf) and charge-transfer resistance (R ct) compared to NCM@TNB [66]. After 50 cycles, the R sf and R ct of NCM increase dramatically, contrasting sharply with the minor variation observed in NCM@TNB. When the cathode loading reaches 13.8 or even 20.2 mg cm−2 (Fig. 7e and Fig. S17), the capacity retention of NCM@TNB/LPSCl/Li-In at 0.3 C after 100 cycles is 88%, while that of NCM/LPSCl/Li-In decrease to 30%. The discussions indicate that NCM@TNB owns superior interfacial charge transfer dynamics and efficaciously mitigates the generation of side reactions. The enhanced reversibility and stability enable NCM@TNB to retain a high capacity over time. 4 Conclusions To summarize, combined with the sol–gel method and high-temperature annealing, a mechanically stable Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 was coated on the surface of NCM. Related structural characterization verifies the achievement of surface oxygen “point to point” anchoring, which enhances the stability of surface oxygen. The segregation of Ti and Nb toward near bulk induced by the charge–discharge process inhibits the outward migration of Oα−(α < 2) and strengthens the lattice oxygen steadiness. Taken together, NCM@TNB has a more stable structure than NCM. With the improvement of the structural stability of NCM@TNB, the generation of intragranular cracks and lattice distortion decreases. Furthermore, the Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 layer prevents the cathode from generating more side reactions with sulfide solid-state electrolyte and improves the internal electronic conductivity of the cathode material. Conclusively, the initial discharge capacity of NCM@TNB reaches 191.4 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, and the capacity retention rate can be maintained at 91% after 1000 cycles at 0.3 C. This work provides an extensible strategy for constructing surface engineering of Ni-rich cathode materials and accomplishing ASSLBs with high energy density and long life. coredata.dc:description: To satisfy the demands of modern society for high-energy–density sulfide-based all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs), Ni-rich cathode materials have gained much attention for their high capacity and energy density. However, their practical deployment is hindered by accelerated interface degradation and capacity decay originating from surface oxygen release and lattice oxygen activation during prolonged cycling. In this study, Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 was successfully coated on the surface of LiNi0.94Co0.05Mn0.01O2. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations first elucidate a “point-to-point” anchoring mechanism where each surface oxygen atom coordinates with single species (Ti/Nb/B) offered by Ti x NbB(1− x )C2, which forms robust O–M bonds and sustain a stable interface structure. The electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) reveals the segregation of Ti/Nb toward subsurface layers during cycling, creating an optimized lattice oxygen coordination environment and suppressing oxygen activation. The dual oxygen stabilization mechanism dramatically improves the reversibility of phase transition and the structural stability of the Ni-rich cathode materials. Moreover, Ti x NbB(1− x )C2 as the protective layer decreases mechanical strain and suppresses the parasitic reactions. Consequently, the engineered cathode delivers 91% capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 0.3 C, suggesting excellent cycling stability. The research delivers a new design philosophy for the coating layer that can stabilize surface oxygen. Furthermore, the atomistic understanding of the structure–property relationship of the Ni-rich cathode materials provides valuable guidance for the future design of new cathode materials with superior structural stability in ASSLBs.
